With the pandemic and online schooling, it has become increasingly difficult to get high school students to volunteer. A recent conversation at an event brought up the question of whether this is an issue across the country. What can we do to encourage engagement from our youth? It's important to remember that volunteering not only helps the community but also provides valuable experience for students. Encouraging high schools to include volunteer work as part of their curriculum can make it easier for students to find opportunities and fulfill their requirements. Additionally, partnering with local organizations and promoting volunteer opportunities on social media can help spread awareness and encourage students to get involved. Let's work together to inspire the next generation to give back to their communities and make a positive impact. Have you had success with engaging high school students in volunteering? Share your tips in the comments below. #volunteering #youthengagement #communityimpact

Normalizing mentorship and volunteering is essential to combat the hidden crisis of juvenile delinquency that is plaguing our communities and crippling future generations. Too often, the potential of our youth is overshadowed by the challenges they face, including lack of guidance, support, and positive role models. Mentorship provides young people with a trusted confidant who can offer advice, share life experiences, and help navigate the complexities of growing up. Similarly, volunteering creates opportunities for adults to invest time and resources into nurturing the next generation, fostering a sense of community and belonging. It‚Äôs time to get off the sidelines and add value to a young person‚Äôs life. Whether it‚Äôs through formal programs or informal connections, we all have the capacity to make a difference. By dedicating a few hours each month, we can inspire, guide, and support youth, helping them develop the skills and confidence needed to succeed. Let‚Äôs work together to ensure that every young person has the opportunity to thrive. Our future depends on it. #Mentorship #Volunteering #YouthDevelopment #CommunitySupport #JuvenileJustice

As we celebrate the incredible contributions of our volunteers this #VolunteersWeek, it‚Äôs crucial to acknowledge that, according to Sport England‚Äôs latest Active Lives Adult Survey (2022-23), there are 2.1 million (5.6%) fewer volunteers now than there were in 2016-17. This statistic is a stark reminder of the challenges we face in maintaining a robust and diverse volunteer workforce. Our #Born2Coach movement aims to reverse this decline. Because, for the nation to thrive, coaching must too. The survey also reveals that while volunteer levels continue to recover, they remain down for most Asian, Black and minority ethnic groups. This underlines the importance of UK Coaching‚Äôs efforts to ensure that volunteering opportunities are accessible and appealing to all sections of our community. Through our #Born2Coach campaign we are looking to recruit more people from more diverse backgrounds into coaching. Interestingly, more people are volunteering regularly now than three years ago. However, an underlying long-term downward trend continues. These findings underscore the urgency of our mission. We need to not only halt the decline but also build back stronger, ensuring that our volunteer workforce is diverse, resilient, and capable of meeting the challenges of the future.
